title.description: A brief title for the rule that should contain what the rules is supposed to detect

id.description: A globally unique identifier for the Sigma rule. This is recommended to be a UUID v4, but not mandatory.

related.description: A list of related Sigma rules to keep track of the relationships between detections. This can be used to indicate that a rule is derived from another rule, or that a rule has been obsoleted by another rule.

id.description: A globally unique identifier for the Sigma rule. This is recommended to be a UUID v4, but not mandatory.

oneOf.description: The rule was derived from the referred rule or rules, which may remain active
The rule obsoletes the referred rule or rules, which aren't used anymore
The rule was merged from the referred rules. The rules may be still existing and in use

The rule had previously the referred identifier or identifiers but was renamed for whatever reason, e.g. from a private naming scheme to UUIDs, to resolve collisions etc. It's not expected that a rule with this id exists anymore
Use to relate similar rules to each other (e.g. same detection content applied to different log sources, rule that is a modified version of another rule with a different level)

name.description: a unique human-readable name that can be used instead of the id as a reference in correlation rules

taxonomy.description: Defines the taxonomy used in the Sigma rule

oneOf.description: The rule didn't produce any obvious false positives in multiple environments over a long period of time
The rule doesn't show any obvious false positives on a limited set of test systems
A new rule that hasn't been tested outside of lab environments and could lead to many false positives
The rule was replaced or is now covered by another one. The link between both rules is made via the `related` field
The rule can not be used in its current state (special correlation log, home-made fields, etc.)

description.description: A short description of the rule and the malicious activity that can be detected

license.description: License of the rule according the SPDX ID specification (https://spdx.dev/ids/)

author.description: Creator of the rule. (can be a name, nickname, twitter handle, etc.)

references.description: References to the source that the rule was derived from. These could be blog articles, technical papers, presentations or even tweets

date.description: Creation date of the rule. Use the ISO 8601 format YYYY-MM-DD

modified.description: Last modification date of the rule. Use the ISO 8601 format YYYY-MM-DD

logsource.description: The log source that the rule is supposed to detect malicious activity in.

category.description: Group of products, like firewall or process_creation

service.description: A subset of a product's logs, like sshd

definition.description: can be used to describe the log source

detection.description: A set of search-identifiers that represent properties of searches on log data

additionalProperties.description: A Search Identifier: A definition that can consist of two different data structures - lists and maps.

condition.description: The relationship between the search identifiers to create the detection logic. Ex: selection1 or selection2

fields.description: A list of log fields that could be interesting in further analysis of the event and should be displayed to the analyst

falsepositives.description: A list of known false positives that may occur

level.description: The criticality of a triggered rule

oneOf.description: Rule is intended for enrichment of events, e.g. by tagging them. No case or alerting should be triggered by such rules because it is expected that a huge amount of events will match these rules
Notable event but rarely an incident. Low rated events can be relevant in high numbers or combination with others. Immediate reaction shouldn't be necessary, but a regular review is recommended
Relevant event that should be reviewed manually on a more frequent basis
Relevant event that should trigger an internal alert and requires a prompt review
Highly relevant event that indicates an incident. Critical events should be reviewed immediately. It is used only for cases in which probability borders certainty

tags.description: Tags to categorize a Sigma rule.

scope.description: A list of intended scope of the rule
